00058 //------------- Main page
00059 
00060 /**
00061 \mainpage  Feature Characterization Library
00062 
00063 <b>Copyright (2000) Sandia Corporation.</b> Under the terms of Contract
00064 DE-AC04-94AL85000 with Sandia Corporation, the U.S. Government retains
00065 certain rights in this software. For full copyright text see 
00066 \ref copyright.
00067 
00068 \section QuickOverview Quick Overview
00069 
00070 The Feature Characterization Library (FCLib) is a toolkit for creating
00071 and applying feature characterizations to spatial-temporal datasets.
00072 Features are coherent structures, often called regions of interest, that 
00073 persist over time in a dataset. Some examples of features include:
00074 vertex tubes in fluid dynamical systems, failure zones in mechanical systems,
00075 and hot spots in chemical systems. Feature characterization is the analysis
00076 of these features.
00077 
00078 FCLib is the first product of the FCDMF project (part of the
00079 ASC Data Discovery Project) which is researching feature extraction and
00080 characterization in large scale scientific datasets.
00081 
00082 <a href="overview_page.html">(More overview ...)</a>
00083 
00084 \section MoreDocumentation Documentation
00085   - \ref install_page
00086   - \ref releaseNotes_page
00087   - \ref navigation_page
00088   - \ref misc_page
00089   - Example codes with annotations in \ref Examples
00090   - Developers - see "for developers" pages in 
00091     <a href="pages.html">Related Pages</a>
00092 
00093 \section Contacts Contacts
00094   - FCLib home page - <a target="_top" href="http://fclib.ca.sandia.gov">
00095     http://fclib.ca.sandia.gov</a>
00096   - FCLib help - <a href=mailto:fclib-help@ca.sandia.gov>
00097     fclib-help@ca.sandia.gov</a>
00098   - FCLib feedback: Please provide feedback to help us improve the FCLib 
00099     experience - <a href=mailto:fclib-help@ca.sandia.gov>fclib-help@ca.sandia.gov</a>
00100

00172 
00173 //------------- Manual navigation page
00174 
00175 /**
00176 \page navigation_page Getting Started with This Manual
00177 
00178 The purpose of this page is to explain the overall organization of this
00179 manual so that the user can find the information that he or she is 
00180 looking for. (Not what you were looking for? See also \ref MoreDocumentation.)
00181 
00182 \section ManualTOC Table of Contents:
00183 
00184    - \ref AboutDoxygen
00185    - \ref DoxygenGuide
00186       - \ref HeaderSideBar
00187       - \ref MoreSideBar
00188    - \ref FCLibNavigation
00189       - \ref DoxygenModules
00190       - \ref TopLevelModules
00191       - \ref APIModules
00192       - \ref ModulesAndSideBar
00193 
00194 \section AboutDoxygen About Doxygen
00195 
00196 This manual was generated using <a
00197 href=http://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/index.html>Doxygen</a> which
00198 automates creating documentation from the source code and special comments
00199 inserted in the code. Because the documentation is spatially co-located with
00200 the objects it is documenting, it tends to be more up-to-date.  Unfortunately
00201 for new users, this mode of documentation tends to favor reference
00202 documentation with detailed documentation on each function or data
00203 structure--if you don't already know what you are looking for, it can be quite
00204 hard to find. Here we will give information that will hopefully let you
00205 navigate the documentation better and point to the places that are best for
00206 learning higher level information.
00207 
00208 \section DoxygenGuide General Doxygen Navigation
00209 
00210 Almost everything in the Doxygen documentation is linked to more documentation.
00211 Even the functions and variables in code snippets are linked to their
00212 documentation.  Sometimes you may have to follow a few links to get to the
00213 information that you want (this may be a side effect of Doxygen being designed
00214 for C++ and the library only being in C).
00215 
00216 \subsection HeaderSideBar Header and Side Bar
00217 
00218 The header is the purple band that you will find at the top of every page
00219 in this manual. The side bar is a separate frame at the left hand side of the
00220 window showing a list of document and book icons.  The header and the side bar
00221 give you access to the same information, but in a slightly different way.  The
00222 advantage of the side-bar is that you can view hierarchical organizations (see
00223 \ref MoreSideBar below).
00224 
00225 Below is a summary of the categories in the header. The most important one for
00226 learning about the library is <em>Modules</em> because it will allow you
00227 to navigate the documentation by subject. This will be the main subject of 
00228 section \ref FCLibNavigation below.
00229 
00230 <table>
00231 <tr>
00232    <td>Main Page</td> 
00233    <td> (Or "Feature Characterization Library" in the side bar) Will take you
00234       to the main page of the manual. </td>
00235 </tr>
00236 <tr>
00237    <td><strong>Modules</strong></td>
00238    <td><strong>FCLib's organization of of the documentation by 
00239        subject.</strong></td> 
00240 </tr>
00241 <tr>
00242    <td>Data Structures</td>
00243    <td>(Also "Alphabetical List" in the header) List of the data 
00244        structures.</td>
00245 </tr>
00246 <tr>
00247    <td>Data Fields</td> 
00248    <td>List of data fields (e.g. struct members).</td>
00249 </tr> 
00250 <tr>
00251    <td>Globals</td>
00252    <td>List of everything except data structures and data fields (e.g. 
00253        variables, functions, enum values, etc.).</td> 
00254 </tr>
00255 <tr>
00256    <td>File List</td>
00257    <td>List of all of the source files.</td>
00258 </tr>
00259 <tr>
00260    <td>Related Pages</td>
00261    <td>List of pages (like this one!) with information not directly related to
00262        particular data structures or functions in the library.</td>
00263 </tr>
00264 </table>
00265 
00266 \subsection MoreSideBar More about the Side Bar
00267 
00268 The side bar shows the manual documentation in a hierarchical view.  The top
00269 level of the hierarchy is the same categories that are in the header.  Clicking
00270 the <em>name</em> of a page or book icon in the side bar will bring up the
00271 documentation for that entity in the main part of the window.  Clicking the
00272 book icon itself, or the little box to the left of it, will expand the view of
00273 the entities contained within that icon. Clicking a document icon does
00274 nothing--you need to click the name.
00275 
00276 \section FCLibNavigation FCLib Specific Doxygen Navigation
00277 
00278 \subsection DoxygenModules Modules
00279 
00280 For the Doxygen documentation, a <em>module</em> is a means of
00281 collecting related documentation into a single page and modules can be
00282 nested. FCLib also uses the term module to refer to related groupings of
00283 functions that are usually in the same file; there is a close, but not
00284 strict, correspondence between FCLib code modules and our Doxygen modules.
00285 
00286 We will use the side bar to walk through the organization of the FCLib's module
00287 documentation because you will be able to see the organization while
00288 staying on this page. However, we do not recommend using the side bar for
00289 exploring the documentation as there is more information if you go
00290 to the pages directly.
00291 
00292 Clicking "Modules" will take you to the top level Modules page where you can
00293 see the entire module hierarchy.  Clicking any module will take you to a page
00294 for the module where you can see the documentation for the module, links to
00295 modules within that module, and the documentation for data structures and
00296 routines. Child modules will also have a link back to their parent module.
00297 
00298 \subsection TopLevelModules Top Level Modules
00299 
00300 If you click the book icon named "Modules" it will expand to show you the top 
00301 level organization of the library:
00302 
00303 <table>
00304 <tr>
00305    <td>\ref API</td> 
00306    <td>Data structures and routines for building feature 
00307        characterizations. </td>
00308 </tr>
00309 <tr>
00310    <td>\ref Tools</td>
00311    <td>Helper tools and a few pre-built feature characterization 
00312        applications.</td> 
00313 </tr>
00314 <tr>
00315    <td>\ref Examples</td>
00316    <td>Example codes showing library usage.</td>
00317 </tr>
00318 </table>
00319 
00320 Now click the book icons next to "Command line tools" and "Examples" to open
00321 them. These two modules contain a module for each tool and example. 
00322 If you click text "Command line tools", you will get a page that lists the same
00323 tools you see in the side bar, and a brief explanation for each.
00324 
00325 \subsection APIModules API Modules
00326 
00327 The FCLib API is the core of the library and its modules are more deeply nested
00328 than either the tools or the examples. If you click the book icon next to
00329 "FCLib API" you will see a list of top level modules in the API. These modules
00330 can be categorized roughly as:
00331 
00332 <table>
00333 <tr>
00334    <td>Data Manipulation</td> 
00335    <td>\ref DataTypes, \ref SimpleDataObjects, \ref DataInterface </td>
00336 </tr>
00337 <tr>
00338    <td>Support</td>
00339    <td>\ref Utilities, \ref ErrorHandling</td> 
00340 </tr>
00341 <tr>
00342    <td>Characterizations and Building Blocks</td>
00343    <td>\ref GeometricRelations, \ref TopologyRelations, \ref VariableMath,
00344        \ref Statistics, \ref Threshold, \ref Features, \ref FeatureTracking,
00345        and more ...</td>
00346 <tr>
00347    <td>Developer sandbox (play area)</td>
00348    <td>\ref Custom</td>
00349 </tr>
00350 </table>
00351 
00352 For more details, go the the page for the \ref API module which will
00353 give a description for each of these modules. We recommend starting with \ref 
00354 DataInterface. Some of the child modules are labeled ("Private") which means 
00355 that we think the contents are not interesting to the general user.
00356 
00357 Have fun!
00358 
00359 \subsection ModulesAndSideBar (Aside: Modules and the Side Bar)
00360 
00361 Unlike the Modules page, which shows the hierarchical organization of only the
00362 modules, the side bar list goes to all the way down to individual data
00363 structures and functions. If you open the module <em>Simple Data Types</em>
00364 within <em>FCLib API</em> you will see book icons for <em>Typedefs</em>,
00365 <em>Enumerations</em>, and <em>Functions</em>--these are Doxygen's syntactic
00366 breakdown of the data structures and routines found within that module (other
00367 possible categories are <em>Data Structures</em>, <em>Defines</em>, and
00368 <em>Variables</em>). If you open these you will see the specific typedefs,
00369 enumerations, and functions within the module.
00370 
00371 */
00372 
00373 //------------- FCLib misc page
00374 
00375 /**
00376 \page misc_page FCLib Coding Conventions & Tips
00377 
00378 This is a summary of general philosophy and coding tips for FCLib. Links
00379 are provided to more detailed information when available.
00380 
00381 - <strong>Compiling</strong>. To compile a program, you must include the
00382 appropriate headers (fc.h automatically includes all library headers for you)
00383 and you must link to the library (fclib.a). You will also need to link to
00384 external libraries for file IO. You can import the file Makefile.include from
00385 your FCLib build directory to use the same build parameters. Or you can
00386 use the tool \ref fcinfo to get the compiler flags.
00387 
00388 - <strong>API Modules</strong>. The API is split into categories called
00389 modules, each of which groups related data structures and functions into
00390 separate compiled units.  These are located in the modules directory and
00391 consist of one .c file and one or two .h files. For example, the geometric
00392 relations module consists of the files geom.c, geom.h and geomP.h. Module
00393 headers can be included separately if desired, but they have dependencies and
00394 must be included in the proper order--it's much easier to use the super header
00395 file, fc.h. FCLib modules correspond roughly with the Doxygen documentation
00396 modules (see \ref FCLibNavigation).
00397 
00398 - <strong>Public vs. Private</strong>. The API of each module is split into
00399 public and private functions. Private functions are generally either helpers
00400 for other functions, or are functions that are only expected to be used
00401 internally by the library. Private functions are not required to have the same
00402 level of error checking and robustness of public functions. To use private
00403 functions you must include the private headers, which have the same names as
00404 the public headers post-fixed with a 'P' (e.g. the public and private headers
00405 for the geometric relations module are geom.h and geomP.h, respectively). You
00406 can include all of the private headers using fcP.h.
00407 
00408 - <strong>Naming conventions</strong>. Data objects are prefixed with 'FC_' and
00409 functions are prefixed with 'fc_'. Private data objects and functions which are
00410 prefixed with '_FC_' and '_fc_', respectively.
00411 
00412 - <strong>Indexing conventions</strong>. All indices and IDs in the library are
00413 indexed from 0.
00414 
00415 - <strong>Function return values</strong>. Most library functions will return
00416 the enumerated type \ref FC_ReturnCode, which reports that the functions was
00417 successful (FC_SUCCESS = 0) or encodes the type of error that occured (< 0).  A
00418 few simple functions return useful values directly (e.g. fc_isDatasetValid()
00419 returns true (1) or false(0)).
00420 
00421 - <strong>Returning results from functions</strong>. In C, functions return a
00422 single value, which for most cases in the library will be an FC_ReturnCode
00423 value. This means that most of the "returned" results from FCLib functions are
00424 not returned at all, but are values assigned to arguments passed into the
00425 functions. For the remainder of the documentation, the use of "returned" will
00426 usually mean a value returned via the arguments of the function. In the Doxygen
00427 documentation, these arguments are labeled as "output" arguments and are
00428 usually a pointer to the memory where the caller would like the results to be
00429 stored.
00430 
00431 - <strong>Messages and Logging</strong>. Library routines can print
00432 errors to stderr or logging messages to stdout. This is set globally by
00433 a call to the library to set its verbosity level (see \ref Library).
00434 
00435 - <strong>Flushing IO</strong>. To get the most predictable IO behavior
00436 on all systems, we recommend calling fflush(NULL) after calling printf() or
00437 fprintf(). This forces a flush of all IO pipes. All fc_printXXX() functions
00438 should flush themselves.
00439 
00440 - <strong>Philosophy of simple data objects</strong>. The library has attempted
00441 to have the simplest interface possible by keeping the interface for the major
00442 data objects as abstract as possible. For example, there is only one kind of
00443 variable instead of different variable types for each type of mesh entity (e.g.
00444 node variables, element variables, etc.). The handling of different types of
00445 variables is hidden inside of the characterizations. This makes it simple for
00446 users to string together characterizations and characterization building blocks
00447 into useful applications. However, characterization developers have the
00448 responsibility of ensuring that their characterizations behave properly on all
00449 variable types.
00450 
00451 - <strong>Handles</strong>. The major data objects are hidden behind opaque
00452 handles; you cannot access their data directly and must go through library
00453 functions (see \ref Handles).
00454 
00455 - <strong>Meta-data vs Big Data</strong>. Meta-data is small data describing
00456 the data objects while big data is the big data making up the data objects
00457 (e.g. the number of vertices in a mesh is meta data while the coordinates of
00458 the vertices in the mesh are big data). When querying data objects, all data
00459 except big data is returned as a copy of the objects data. If any of this meta
00460 data happens to be an array, the users has received a dynamically allocated
00461 memory and is responsible for freeing it. When asking for big data, however,
00462 the user receives a pointer to the object's data and <strong>must not free
00463 it</strong>! The calls that return a pointer to big data are distinguished from
00464 regular data calls by being postfixed by 'Ptr'
00465 (e.g. fc_getMeshCoordsPtr()). When creating data objects, you have the choice
00466 of having the library copy the big data or giving responsibility for the big
00467 data to the data object. The functions that give the big data array to the
00468 library are also postfixed with 'Ptr' and if you use them, again you must not
00469 free the array.
00470 
00471 - <strong>Non-library-managed data objects</strong>. In addition to the major
00472 data objects that are managed by the library (FC_Dataset, FC_Sequence, FC_Mesh,
00473 FC_Subset, FC_Variable), there are auxiliary data objects including sorted int
00474 arrays (\ref FC_SortedIntArray), vertex bins for spatially sorting vertices 
00475 (\ref FC_VertexBin), feature groups for managing features 
00476 (\ref FC_FeatureGroup), etc. These objects are not automatically freed when 
00477 you close a dataset or the library. Instead, each has a separate fc_freeX() 
00478 routine.
00479 
00480 */
00481

00486 \htmlinclude FCLib_installation.html

00503 //------------- Release How To page (convert from html file)

00507 \htmlinclude FCLib_releaseHowTo.html
00508 */
00509 
00510 //------------- Style for documentation
00511 
00512 /**
00513 \page dox_page  Conventions for Doxygen documentation (for developers)
00514 
00515 This page describes FCLib specific conventions for creating comments blocks
00516 that produce the Doxygen documentation.
00517 
00518 \section DoxTOC Table of Contents:
00519 
00520  - \ref CommentBlocks
00521  - \ref DoxygenCommands
00522  - \ref FormattedLists
00523  - \ref Modules
00524  - \ref ExampleModule
00525  - \ref ExampleFile
00526  - \ref ExampleFunction
00527  - \ref ExamplePage
00528 
00529 
00530 \section CommentBlocks Doxygen comment blocks
00531 
00532 Doxygen only examines comments that are marked as special. For example
00533 
00534 \verbatim
00535 /**  
00536  * This is a Doxygen comment block because it starts with an
00537  * an extra '*'.
00538    '*'s on middle lines are optional.
00539  */
00540 
00541 /* 
00542  * This is a normal 
00543  * comment block
00544  */
00545 \endverbatim
00546 
00547 Doxygen comment blocks usually proceed the entity (function, struct, etc)
00548 that they define. An exception is for function arguments and members of
00549 structs and enums where a special character ('<') is used to indicate that
00550 the comment has come after the entity.
00551 
00552 Here is an example of documentation for a struct
00553 
00554 \verbatim
00555 /** documentation for some_struct */
00556 struct { 
00557    int member1; /**< documentation for member1 */
00558    int member2; /**< documentation for member2 */
00559 } some_struct;
00560 \endverbatim
00561 
00562 
00563 \section DoxygenCommands Doxygen commands
00564 
00565 Doxygen commands start with a backslash ('\') and are used to specify extra
00566 formatting, what entities the documentation belongs to, etc. They can have
00567 a few different types of arguments:
00568 
00569   - <argument> - the argument is is a single word 
00570   - (argument) - the argument extends until the end of the line on
00571     which it is found
00572   - {argument} - the argument extends until the next paragraph. Paragraphs
00573     are delimited by a blank line or by a section indicator.
00574 
00575 Note that many entities have a name (single token identifier) \b and a title
00576 (phrase used for display).
00577 
00578 We are using the following subset of Doxygen commands (these are the FCLib uses
00579 for these commands, see Doxygen's documentation for their general purpose
00580 usage):
00581 
00582 \verbatim
00583 \addtogroup <name> (title) - will define a group like \defgroup if <name>
00584    has already been used, or will append this comment blocks documentation
00585    to previous documentation for the group.
00586 
00587 \b <word> - displays word in bold. To put multiple words in bold use
00588   <b>multiple words<\b>.
00589 
00590 \brief {brief description} - Provide one sentence summary of entity.
00591 
00592 \bug {bug description} - Comments about code that is suspect (will show up on 
00593    current entity and on separate 'Bug List' Page).
00594  
00595 \defgroup <module_name> (module title) - defines a module (a module is a
00596    user defined grouping of entities).
00597 
00598 \htmlinclude <file_name> - paste html file in as-is.
00599 
00600 \ingroup <module_name> - add entity to the module 
00601 
00602 \file <file_name> - Specify that block is documentation for a file.
00603 
00604 \page <page_name> (page_title) - indicates comment block that contains 
00605   documentation not directly related to entities like functions, files, etc.
00606 
00607 \ref <name> - will make a hyper-link to the named entity.
00608 
00609 \sa {references} - Produces bold face 'See also' before the references.
00610 
00611 \section <section_name> (section title) - starts a new section in the current 
00612    comment block
00613 
00614 \subsection <subsection_name> (subsection title) - starts a new subsection in 
00615    the current
00616 
00617 \todo {to do description} - Comments of things that need to be done (will show
00618   up on current entity and on separate 'Todo List' Page).
00619 
00620 \verbatim/endverbatim - these commands are used to bracket text that will 
00621    appear exactly as typed (Doxygen commands disabled within).
00622 \endverbatim
00623 
00624 
00625 We have defined the following aliases for our project:
00626 
00627 \verbatim
00628  \description - Inserts a bold face 'Description:'.
00629 
00630  \modifications - Inserts a bold face 'Modifications:'.
00631 \endverbatim
00632 
00633 
00634 
00635 \section FormattedLists Bulleted and Numbered Lists
00636 
00637 Lists and nested lists can be easily created.
00638 
00639 \verbatim
00640 /**
00641  * The bulleted list:  
00642  *  - item
00643  *     - subitem
00644  *     - subitem
00645  *  - item
00646  *  - ....
00647  */
00648 \endverbatim
00649 
00650 The above comment produces:
00651 
00652 The bulleted list:  
00653   - item
00654      - subitem
00655      - subitem
00656   - item2 
00657   - ....
00658 
00659 Numbered lists can also be made, but the subitems are not properly numbered
00660 (a bulleted list inside a numbered list works fine).
00661 
00662 \verbatim
00663 /**
00664  * The numbered list:  
00665  *  -# item
00666  *     -# subitem
00667  *     -# subitem
00668  *  -# item
00669  *  -# ....
00670  */
00671 \endverbatim
00672 
00673 The above comment produces:
00674 
00675 The numbered list:  
00676   -# item
00677      -# subitem
00678      -# subitem
00679   -# item
00680   -# ....
00681 
00682 
00683 
00684 \section Modules Modules
00685 
00686 The data types and functions in FCLib are grouped together into user-defined
00687 modules for easier reference. Top level module definitions are created like
00688 this:
00689 
00690 \verbatim
00691 /** 
00692  * \defgroup  API FCLib API
00693  */
00694 \endverbatim
00695 
00696 which defines a group named 'API' and titled 'FCLib API'. Submodules
00697 can be defined like this:
00698 
00699 \verbatim
00700 /**
00701  * \ingroup  API
00702  * \defgroup DataInterface Data Interface
00703  */
00704 \endverbatim
00705 
00706 Any entities that you want to appear in a module should have an 'ingroup'
00707 command in their documentation.
00708 
00709 The top level modules for FCLib are declared in \ref doxy_module_defs to insure
00710 that the appear in the documentation in the desired order. Further
00711 documentation is added to some of the groups in the appropriate source files
00712 using the 'addtogroup' command (see next section).
00713 
00714 
00715 
00716 \section ExampleModule Example: Module documentation
00717 
00718 Below are code snippets to create a (fictitious) module and its
00719 two submodules.
00720  
00721 In file \ref doxy_module_defs :
00722 \verbatim
00723 /**
00724  * \defgroup API FCLib API
00725  * \brief Feature Characterization Library API
00726  *
00727  * \description
00728  *
00729  *    ...
00730  */
00731 
00732 ...
00733 
00734     /** 
00735      * \ingroup API
00736      * \defgroup ExampleModuleTag Example Module Name 
00737      */
00738 
00739 ...
00740 \endverbatim
00741 
00742 and in example_module.c:
00743 \verbatim
00744 /**
00745  * \addtogroup  ExampleModuleTag
00746  * \brief  One sentence explanation about the example module
00747  *
00748  * \description
00749  * 
00750  *    General, detailed text about the example module
00751  *
00752  *   ...
00753  */
00754 
00755 /**
00756  * \ingroup  ExampleModuleTag
00757  * \defgroup SubModule1Tag Submodule 1
00758  */
00759 
00760 /**
00761  * \ingroup  ExampleModuleTag
00762  * \defgroup SubModule2Tab Submodule 2  
00763  *
00764  * \brief Can add text here to explain submodule.
00765  */
00766 
00767 
00768 ...
00769 \endverbatim
00770 
00771 Note the use of the 'addtogroup' command to provide documentation to the
00772 module because it had already been defined. This is done so that the
00773 documentation for module can be maintained in the appropriate .c file.
00774 
00775 
00776 
00777 \section ExampleFile Example: File documentation
00778  
00779 In addition to entity documentation within files, each source file should also
00780 be documented as a file. Here is an example of the minimum required documentation
00781 for FCLib source files:
00782 
00783 \verbatim
00784 /** 
00785  * \file  some_file.h
00786  * \brief Public declarations for the \ref SomeModule Module.
00787  *
00788  * $ Source$              (but without space between '$' and the word
00789  * $ Revision$             which we had to do here to prevent CVS
00790  * $ Date$                 from messing up our documentation).
00791  */
00792 \endverbatim
00793 
00794 where Source, Revision, and Date (when between '$'s) are helpful cvs
00795 keywords. Files that are the source for command line programs will generally
00796 have extensive documentation in the the file comment block (for example, see
00797 source code for \ref fcdump.c).
00798 
00799 
00800 
00801 \section ExampleFunction Example: Function documentation
00802 
00803 Here is an example of how to document a function. The format is essential the
00804 same for structs, enums, typedefs, global variables, defines, etc.
00805 
00806 \verbatim
00807 /**
00808  * \ingroup  SomeModule
00809  * \brief  This function does something.
00810  *
00811  * \description
00812  *
00813  *    This function does something by first examining it's arguments and
00814  *    and then manipulating them this way and that:
00815  *      - first it squeezes them
00816  *      - then it freezes them
00817  *      - and finally it sneezes them
00818  *
00819  *    After all of that, it calls \ref another_function and returns a number.
00820  *
00821  * \todo Somebody really ought to rewrite this vague documentation
00822  *
00823  * \bug This functions doesn't handle candy types yet!
00824  *
00825  * \modifications  
00826  *    - 01/02/03  JD,  Created.
00827  *    - 01/04/03  PNT, Added handling of savory types
00828  */
00829 int some_function(
00830   Snack* snack,  /**< input/output - a pointer to the snack to be modified */
00831   int numSalt,   /**< input - the number of salt grains to add*/
00832   int* shouldIEatIt  /**< output - flag for whether to eat the snack */
00833 ) {
00834   // check input
00835   if (!snack || numSalt < 0)
00836     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00837 
00838   ...
00839 }
00840 \endverbatim
00841 
00842 Most functions (structs, enums, etc) should be in a module so use the command
00843 'ingroup' to specify which module this documentation belongs to.  Next provide
00844 a brief description and a blank line (brief descriptions must always be
00845 followed by a blank line unless they are the last command in the comment
00846 block).
00847 
00848 The rest of the documentation is considered the detailed description. The
00849 description command just produces a bold 'Description:' as a heading. The
00850 'todo' and 'bug' commands create headings and also put their comments on the
00851 \ref todo and \ref bug pages. The 'modification' command also produces a
00852 bold heading and it an FCLib convention to put each modification in a list
00853 with the date, modifiers initials, and a brief comment.
00854 
00855 The arguments of functions should also be documented. It is an FCLib 
00856 convention to start the comment with 'input' (argument is purely for input),
00857 'output' (argument is purely for output), or 'input/out' (argument that
00858 is modified). Be sure to use '-' after this tag--for some reason Doxygen
00859 does not like ':'.
00860 
00861 
00862 \section ExamplePage Example: Page documentation
00863 
00864 Pages are entities that are used to generate documentation that isn't
00865 associated with actual code entities like functions or variables.
00866 Here is a section of the file used to create this page:
00867 
00868 \verbatim
00869 /*
00870 \page page1  FCLib conventions for Doxygen documentation (for developers)
00871 
00872 This page describes FCLib specific conventions for creating comments blocks
00873 that produce the Doxygen documentation.
00874 
00875 \section TOC Table of Contents:
00876 
00877  - \ref CommentBlocks
00878  - \ref DoxygenCommands
00879  
00880 ...
00881 
00882 \section CommentBlocks Doxygen comment blocks
00883 
00884 Doxygen only examines comments that are marked as special. For example
00885 
00886 \verbatim
00887 /**  
00888  * This is a Doxygen comment block because it starts with an
00889  * an extra '*'.
00890    '*'s on middle lines are optional.
00891  */
00892 
00893 /* 
00894  * This is a normal 
00895  * comment block
00896  */
00897 \ endverbatim
00898 
00899 ...
00900 
00901 */
00902 \endverbatim
00903 
00904 A page comment block is declared with the 'page' command. The documentation
00905 can be broken into sections and subsections which can be referenced, for
00906 example to build a table of contents. 'verbatim/endverbatim' commands can
00907 be used to set off code samples.
00908 
00909 */
00910 
00911 //------------- DesignNotes page (convert from html file)
00912 
00913 /**
00914 \page design_page  Design Notes (for developers)
00915 \htmlinclude FCLib_designNotes.html
00916 */
00917
